Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Iodine in foraminifera as a proxy for ocean deoxygenation during the Paleocene- Eocene Thermal Maximum
Award.AbstractNarration:
Oxygen levels in the ocean are expected to decrease as global warming progresses, with potentially serious implications for marine life. To forecast future changes in ocean oxygen levels, a better understanding is needed of deoxygenation associated with past warming events.

This project, a collaboration between researchers at Syracuse and Yale Universities, will use iodine in benthic foraminiferal tests as a novel proxy for past oxygenation conditions. The research is motivated by the a close relationship between redox conditions and iodate (IO3-) concentrations in seawater, which affect I/Ca values in foraminiferal tests. The project will expand upon preliminary work in order to better calibrate the iodine proxy, then apply it to a study of the Paleocene-Eocene Thermal Maximum (PETM), a warming event that occurred ~55 million years ago. The researchers will reconstruct temporal, bathymetric, and geographic variations in ocean oxygenation during the PETM, using benthic foraminifera in cores collected by the Ocean Drilling Program from the Atlantic, Pacific, and Indian Ocean basins, as well as land sections from the Mediterranean, eastern U.S., and New Zealand. In addition, they will examine the link between deoxygenation and benthic extinctions, and consider patterns of hypoxia/anoxia to assess which factors (e.g., temperature, productivity, circulation, local methane oxidation) most influenced the development of low oxygen conditions.

The researchers will collaborate internationally on proxy refinement with institutions in Germany (GEOMAR) and the UK (Oxford), and will engage policy makers through venues like the Yale Climate and Energy Institute. Funding will support an early-career investigator; additionally, the project will train one PhD, one MS, and two undergraduate students. The project will involve underrepresented high school students through EVOLUTIONS, an NSF-funded after-school program at the Peabody Museum (Yale). Results will be incorporated into university coursework and exhibits targeted at undergraduates.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Global warming will likely continue in the near future. A variety of consequences can be expected for future climate changes. Oxygen levels in the oceans will generally become lower, a condition unfavorable for marine ecosystem. It is still very difficult to forecast the location and the severity of oxygen depletion. We proposed to study the geographic and depth extent of low oxygen conditions during periods of ancient greenhouse climate period, called Paleocene to Eocene time.

We measured the ratio of the element concentration between Iodine and Calcium (I/Ca) in the shells of micro-fossil, foraminifera. These shells are preserved in marine sediments and they provide important information about the conditions when these organisms were alive and forming their shells. I/Ca of these shells can tell us about the oxygen levels in particular. Depending on the type of fossils, we may learn about oxygen near sea surface or on the sea floor. with oxygen in seawater, higher I/Ca values will be found in the foraminifera shells.

To validate our approach, we compared modern foraminifera I/Ca with the oxygen concentrations measured in seawater. We gained confidence in the relationship between shell I/Ca and oxygen. We, then, use this approach in Paleocene-Eocene samples. Despite some complexities, we published our new discoveries in peer-reviewed journals to demonstrate that low oxygen waters in the oceans expanded during periods of past global warming, both vertically and horizontally. By investigating sites in different ocean basins, we suggest the deep oceans had generally less oxygen during these ancient warm periods. This conclusion agrees with findings in climate models (CCSM3 and cGENIE). More work is needed to precisely match details in models to those data generated from fossils.

These results were incorporated in a large introductory class (Climate Change) at Syracuse University with 170-270 students enrolled each year. Students learned about ocean deoxygenation in both modern and ancient oceans related to global warming. Similarly, we took the opportunity to demonstrate our research results to local high school students visiting the Earth Science department. Exhibits were also shown at New York State geology student symposium each year.
